title: Where does the last name 'Savage' come from? - Quora

response.answer_text: From Patronymica Britannica: A Dictionary of Family Names of the United Kingdom, published in 1860: SAVAGE. Camden says, that this surname was introduced into England by a personage in the train of Isabella of France, queen of Edward II. There were, however, earlier settlements of families so named; for a knight of this designation founded the Savages in Ireland immediately upon De Courcy’s invasion, temp. Henry II. Le Sauvage was a sobriquet of early times, both in Normandy and in England, which implied, perhaps, a roughness of manners, like our indigenous Wild. In ancient deeds the common latinization is Salvagius. This name, like many others in England, would have referred to an individual person. In small communities, especially before the Norman Conquest, people went by a single name. But if there was more than one person with that name in the village, descriptive nicknames may have been used to distinguish one from another. Perhaps “savage Will” was considered by his neighbors to be an uncouth lout. That may be how people distinguished him from “black-haired Will” who lived down the road, when they were talking about one or the other. Starting about the 12th century, the government insisted on family names in order to keep tax records, and sometimes these nicknames were pressed into use for that purpose. So these two hypothetical men became “Will Savage” and “Will Black,” and their children used the family names as well. I enjoyed reading Joe Devney’s comment about the surname Savage. There is a small town west of Minneapolis, MN and I always wondered about the origin of the name. I was once told when I was in high school where the name came from, so I always knew it was English and had nothing to do with what some settlers called some of the Native Americans in Southern and Western Minnesota during the late 1800’s

Many English names came from either places, occupations, or nicknames. The name “savage” is first recorded in the Domesday book. It didn’t quite mean “wild and feral” at that point, but could be a nickname for what we’d now call “hot-tempered.” It appears to have become a surname from that. However, later, about the 13th Century, it also got used to people who “went local”, such as English gentry in Scotland who adopted Scottish customs.

“The name Savage is an example of a group of early European surnames that were gradually created from the habitual use of nicknames. The nicknames were given in the first instance with reference to a variety of characteristics, such as physical attributes or peculiarities, mental and moral characteristics, or to habits of dress or occupation. Savage is of early medieval English origin, and derives from the Middle English and Old French "salvage, sauvage" = wild, uncontrolled. Here you get some obvious guesses but unfortunately not the true meaning of my name which actually comes from savvy which with French or Latin roots means intelligent or simply knowing although in practical sense. The y has changed into the g which is a natural etymological development, in turn occasioning the change of the second v to a. But the distinct sense of practical knowledge comes from its connection with the idea of pliable or flexible through some dead eastern European Slavic languages, which now of course even in our English is obvious in ‘apply’ which then makes obvious also the natural development of its connection with people living in the essentially unpredictable wild or forests.
